vignette.presentation:
16. A 6-year-old boy has progressive acute myelogenous leukemia despite numerous therapeutic interventions . During a meeting with his parents to discuss the prognosis and the futility of further treatment , his parents request that
the patient not be told his prognosis . During an examination when his parents are not present , the patient asks if he is going to die soon. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?

question_stem: the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "Have you talked to your parents about this?"
"I have talked to your parents about this, and they do not want you to know."
"Most children with your condition live a long time ."
"No one really knows. It's hard to say."
"That's not the spirit I like to see in my patients."

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The disclosure of a fatal prognosis to pediatric patients is extremely challenging and requires careful balancing of the ethical imperatives to tell the truth, to involve the child in care, and to integrate the family's wishes along with the child's development and mental capabilities. Legally, minors are not considered to be autonomous decision makers and authority to determine what is in the child's best interest lies with the child's parents. In the case of nondisclosure requests by parents, any disclosure to the child should only be made with parental involvement and consent. In response to this child's question, it is best to gauge what discussion has taken place with the child's parents and to probe the child's level of understanding.
explanation.educational_objective: The authority for disclosure of medical information to children rests with the child's parents. In the event of a nondisclosure request, disclosures may only be made with parental consent. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: The authority for disclosure of medical information to children rests with the child's parents. In the event of a nondisclosure request, disclosures may only be made with parental consent. r " , r-- r

vignette.presentation:
17. A newborn is examined 12 hours after birth for excessive oral secretions and coughing following his first feeding . The symptoms resolve after suctioning . Polyhydramnios was diagnosed by ultrasonography at 35 weeks'
gestation. The pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated . He was delivered at term with no complications . Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes , respectively . He weighs 3005 g (6 lb 10 oz). Examination shows no
abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Newborns with esophageal atresia typically present with the inability to feed, with associated gagging and an inability to manage oral secretions. As well, since the fetus is unable to swallow amniotic fluid, the pregnancy may be complicated by polyhydramnios. Esophageal atresia often occurs with a concomitant tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). The presence of a TEF, depending on the subtype, potentially conveys an increased risk for aspiration pneumonia and respiratory distress. Initial evaluation requires an attempt at insertion of a nasogastric tube and evaluation of its position with a chest x-ray. If the nasogastric tube remains coiled within the esophagus, this suggests the presence of esophageal atresia. Air within the gastrointestinal tract immediately after birth and prior to feeding suggests the existence of a TEF distal to the esophageal atresia. Definitive management requires surgical repair. Additional screening for associated congenital malformations should occur.

distractor_explanations.A: Genetic testing can be used to evaluate for chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome. While esophageal atresia is associated with malformation syndromes, it is not commonly correlated with a specific genetic abnormality. Ultrasonography of the abdomen (Choice B) can be used to evaluate for pyloric stenosis and intussusception, among other disorders. As the esophagus typically terminates in the thorax in the setting of esophageal atresia, ultrasonography of the abdomen does not play a role in its diagnosis. CT scan of the chest (Choice C) could potentially outline the patient's anatomy and characterize the esophageal atresia; however, placement of a nasogastric tube and chest x-ray would effectively provide the diagnosis while exposing the patient to less radiation.
distractor_explanations.D: Laryngoscopy is the process of using a laryngoscope or camera to examine the larynx of the patient. As laryngoscopy does not evaluate the esophagus, it does not play a role in the evaluation of esophageal atresia.

explanation.educational_objective: Esophageal atresia presents with an inability to feed and manage oral secretions. If present along with a tracheoesophageal fistula, the patient may present with gagging, coughing, respiratory distress, and cyanosis in the neonatal period. Inability to pass a nasogastric tube with it remaining coiled in the proximal esophagus on chest x-ray is diagnostic. Definitive management requires surgical repair. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Esophageal atresia presents with an inability to feed and manage oral secretions. If present along with a tracheoesophageal fistula, the patient may present with gagging, coughing, respiratory distres

vignette.presentation:
18. A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a mass in the right side of the neck , progressive axillary and inguinal adenopathy , and generalized pruritus . She has had a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss
during this period . Examination shows no other abnormalities . An x-ray of the chest shows a mediastinal mass . Laboratory studies show anemia with a normal leukocyte count and differential , increased erythrocyte
sedimentation rate, and increased serum ferritin concentration . A node biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?

question_stem: most likely to show which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hodgkin disease is a type of lymphoma, predominantly B-cell in origin, that occurs commonly in patients who are 20 to 30 and 55 to 65 years old. Patients typically present with lymphadenopathy, as well as nonspecific constitutional symptoms, such as fever, night sweats, weight loss, and pruritus. The most common sites of lymphadenopathy are the neck and mediastinum. Laboratory values typically demonstrate a normal leukocyte count, anemia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and increased serum ferritin concentration, which are related to the underlying systemic inflammation. Initial evaluation commonly includes a chest x-ray or CT scan, which will potentially outline the extent of the patient's mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. Definitive diagnosis requires excisional lymph node biopsy, which will disclose Reed-Sternberg cells (atypical cells with bilobed nuclei), a large inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophilic predominance, and fibrosis. Hodgkin cells are typically CD15- and CD30-positive. The most common subtype is nodular sclerosing, whereas the worst prognosis occurs in the setting of the lymphocyte-depleted subtype. Risk factors for its development include Ebstein-Barr infection, immunosuppression, and a family history of Hodgkin disease. Treatment includes chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: Cytomegalovirus infection is often asymptomatic but can cause a short febrile, flu-like illness in healthy patients. It can cause severe infections in immunocompromised patients. It does not present with generalized pruritus.
distractor_explanations.C: Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory condition that can affect multiple organ systems, especially the lungs and lymphatic system. It typically presents with a cough, dyspnea, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and potentially with anterior uveitis, erythema nodosum, and arthralgias.
distractor_explanations.D: Thymoma is a benign or malignant tumor of the thymus. It presents with an anterior mediastinal mass, which can cause chest pain or shortness of breath. It is commonly associated with myasthenia gravis. It does not often present with lymphadenopathy.
distractor_explanations.E: Tuberculosis is spread via airborne transmission and can present with a primary, latent, or reactivation pattern. Primary disease demonstrates subacute fever, weight loss, nights sweats, cough, and malaise, whereas latent tuberculosis is commonly asymptomatic. Reactivation presents similarly to primary disease but occurs after a period of latency, typically affecting the lung apices or resulting in miliary disease.

explanation.educational_objective: Hodgkin disease is a type of lymphoma, predominantly B-cell in origin, that demonstrates a bimodal age distribution. It typically presents with lymphadenopathy, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and pruritus. Evaluation commonly shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy, as well as Reed-Sternberg cells on histology. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Hodgkin disease is a type of lymphoma, predominantly B-cell in origin, that demonstrates a bimodal age distribution. It typically presents with lymphadenopathy, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and p

vignette.presentation:
19. A 4½-year-old boy has periorbital and pedal edema and ascites 7 days after an upper respiratory tract infection . Breath sounds are diminished on the right side of the chest. His liver is palpable , and there is 2+ pretibial edema .
Laboratory studies show :
Hematocrit 44%
Serum
Urea nitrogen 6 mg/dl
Creatinine 0.5 mg/dl
Urinalysis shows 4+ protein and no occult blood , WBCs , RBCs , casts , glucose , or ketones . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by edema secondary to excessive proteinuria resulting in hypoalbuminemia and diminished intravascular oncotic pressure. This occurs because of loss of normal size and charge filtration of the glomerular capillary and Bowman capsule interface. Causes of nephrotic syndrome include minimal change disease, membranous nephropathy, and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and can be idiopathic or triggered by a recent infection or immune stimulus. Patients classically present with dependent edema in the buttocks, lower back, and legs, foamy or dark-colored urine, hypoalbuminemia, and proteinuria. Minimal change disease appears normal on light microscopy.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute glomerulonephritis can refer to a variety of glomerular diseases that involve inflammation of glomeruli, which typically present with hematuria, red blood cell urine casts, and hypertension. The patient has severe proteinuria and no RBCs in his urine, making this diagnosis unlikely. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Choice B) is a cause of nephrotic syndrome that can result in proteinuria and pitting edema. FSGS is commonly associated with sickle cell disease, opioid use, and HIV, and is characterized by segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli that is visible on light microscopy. lgA nephropathy (Choice C) is characterized by episodic hematuria that occurs concurrently with upper respiratory tract infections. When lgA deposition occurs in the renal mesangium, glomerulonephritis may ensue, causing microscopic hematuria, erythrocyte casts, and mild to moderate proteinuria. Membranous nephropathy (Choice D) is a nephrotic syndrome which is more common in adults and can be secondary to drugs (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), infections (eg, hepatitis B and C), or systemic lupus erythematosus. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

explanation.educational_objective: Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and can be idiopathic or triggered by a recent infection or immune stimulus. Patients classically present with dependent edema in the buttocks, lower back, and lower extremities, foamy or dark-colored urine, hypoalbuminemia, and proteinuria. Minimal change disease appears normal on light microscopy. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and can be idiopathic or triggered by a recent infection or immune stimulus. Patients classically present with depende

vignette.presentation:
20. A 9-month -old boy has pneumonia for the fourth time . He was born at 28 weeks' gestation with a grade 4 intraventricular hemorrhage and generalized neurologic devastation . Barium swallow shows a grade 4 gastroesophageal
reflux . Which of the following operative procedures is most likely to decrease the frequency of recurrent pneumonia?

question_stem: most likely to decrease the frequency of recurrent pneumonia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The inhalation of orogastric contents is known as aspiration, and it can occur from simple fluids such as water, or from stomach contents as a result of emesis or gastroesophageal reflux, as in this patient. The aspiration of acidic stomach contents may cause aspiration pneumonitis, whereas the aspiration of gastrointestinal flora and bacteria can cause aspiration pneumonia. The volume of aspirate is a strong predictor of complications from aspiration, especially in the case of pneumonia, as the bacterial inoculum may overwhelm the native ability of pulmonary alveolar defense (macrophages, cilia, mucus) to prevent colonization, replication, and infection. Aspiration pneumonia classically presents with a cough productive of foul-smelling sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, and rhonchi on physical examination. Imaging classically shows an infiltrate in the most dependent lung segments at the time of aspiration (eg, in the superior segment of the inferior lobe when supine or lower lobes when erect). Patients at a higher risk for aspiration include those with impaired airway-protective reflexes (eg, neurological injury, myasthenia gravis, altered mental status), frequent or forceful emesis, abnormal pharyngeal or airway anatomy or function (eg, malignancy, tracheoesophageal fistula), or severe gastroesophageal reflux. Options for the management of severe gastroesophageal reflux in children include dietary changes and proton pump inhibitors or histamine- 2 receptor antagonists, although these would not assist in decreasing the risk for aspiration pneumonia. Fundoplication is a surgical procedure that improves the gastroesophageal sphincter tone by wrapping the fundus around the distal esophagus, which decreases the frequency and severity of reflux.

distractor_explanations.A: Esophagostomy is a surgical opening into the esophagus that is occasionally used in head and neck cancer to provide enteral nutrition. It does not play a role in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux.
distractor_explanations.C: Gastrostomy is the surgical creation of an opening into the stomach, which can be used for enteral nutrition or to remove the contents of the stomach via drainage. For this to be effective in preventing aspiration caused by gastroesophageal reflux, the placed tube would have to be placed to suction or to drainage at all times, which would prohibit proper nutrition. Fundoplication is a more reasonable option.
distractor_explanations.D: Pyloromyotomy is a procedure that decreases the strength of the pyloric sphincter. It is used to treat hypertrophic pyloric stenosis but is not used in the management of severe gastroesophageal reflux. Vagotomy and pyloroplasty (Choice E) entails the surgical ligation of the vagus nerve, in addition to the enlargement of the pyloric opening, which is used to treat gastric ulcers. These procedures would not prevent aspiration in this patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Aspiration pneumonia is typically secondary to impaired airway reflexes, abnormal oropharyngeal or tracheal anatomy or function, or severe gastroesophageal reflux with regurgitation of gastric contents. Recurrent aspiration from severe gastroesophageal reflux can be treated with fundoplication, which tightens the gastroesophageal sphincter and decreases the frequency and severity of reflux. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Aspiration pneumonia is typically secondary to impaired airway reflexes, abnormal oropharyngeal or tracheal anatomy or function, or severe gastroesophageal reflux with regurgitation of gastric content

vignette.presentation:
22. A 3-year-old African American girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening , diffuse abdominal pain and loss of appetite . During this time , she has had a 1-kg (2-lb) weight loss . She is at the 50th
percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a firm , nodular midline mass from the mid to upper abdomen . There is pain and swelling of the right wrist.
The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . An x-ray of the abdomen and ultrasonography of the mass show a 12-cm midline mass with multiple calcifications . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neuroblastoma is a neoplasm of neuroendocrine cells of the sympathetic nervous system. It may arise from any sympathetic nervous tissue and is the most common tumor of the adrenal gland that occurs in children. Other locations include the sympathetic chain. Adrenal involvement classically presents with abdominal pain and distention, weight loss, and failure to thrive. Patients may also present with an associated paraneoplastic opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. Physical examination may show a firm, nodular mass that crosses the midline and diastolic hypertension. Diagnosis is suggested by the presence of increased catecholamine metabolites in the serum and urine. Neuroblastoma is associated with overamplification of the MYCN oncogene. Histologic characteristics include small round blue cells that may form rosette patterns clustered around a central lumen, with positive stains for bombesin and neuron-specific enolase markers. Neuroblastoma commonly metastasizes to bone and skin. Treatment and prognosis are dependent on the stage of the tumor at diagnosis and the presence or absence of MYCN amplification.

distractor_explanations.A: Ewing sarcoma is a primary bone malignancy driven by t(11 ;22) chromosomal translocation. On histology, Ewing sarcoma demonstrates multiple small, round, blue cells. X-rays may demonstrate elevated periosteum and layered neocortex formation. It often occurs in the long bones (eg, femur, tibia) and typically presents in adolescence. Multicystic dysplastic kidney (Choice B) is a nonhereditary pediatric cystic renal disease that results from the formation of multiple renal cysts in utero. It is typically sporadic. It can affect one or both kidneys, with a higher incidence of bilateral involvement in females. The affected kidney is replaced by numerous cysts and retains no functioning renal tissue. Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) (Choice D) is the most common renal malignancy in childhood. It occurs secondary to mutations in tumor suppressor genes WT1 or WT2. It is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass and hematuria. It does not typically cross midline and is often smooth to palpation rather than nodular. Polycystic kidney disease (Choice E) refers to either autosomal recessive or dominant polycystic kidney disease. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is a form of infantile cystic renal disease that manifests with the development of numerous small renal cysts that replace the normal renal parenchyma, resulting in end-stage kidney disease. It typically has a variable age of presentation during fetal life or childhood but can be a potential cause of oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia (Potter sequence) if it develops in utero.

explanation.educational_objective: Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroendocrine cells of the sympathetic nervous system that commonly affects the adrenal glands. It may be differentiated from other common abdominal malignancies of childhood by its tendency to cross the mid line and have a nodular texture, along with its association with paraneoplastic opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome and increased concentrations of serum and urine catecholamine metabolites. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroendocrine cells of the sympathetic nervous system that commonly affects the adrenal glands. It may be differentiated from other common abdominal malignancies of c

vignette.presentation:
23. A 12-hour-old male newborn has not urinated since birth . He was born at 36 weeks' gestation to a 15-year-old primigravid patient and weighed 2325 g (5 lb 2 oz). Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes , respectively . His
mother received no prenatal care . During her pregnancy , she smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily and occasional marijuana and drank approximately two beers on the weekends . Since birth , the newborn has received
one ounce of cow's milk-based formula without vomiting and has passed one small meconium stool. He is alert and active . His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) , pulse is 135/min , and respirations are 35/min . Examination shows
no dysmorphic features . The lungs are clear to auscultation . Heart sounds are normal. The lower abdomen is distended with a midline mass . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital urinary tract abnormalities include but are not limited to unilateral renal agenesis, fused kidneys, ureteral stricture and stenosis, duplex collecting system, posterior urethral valves, bladder agenesis, bladder exstrophy, hypo- or epispadias, and urethral strictures. Posterior urethral valves are formed from an abnormal remnant of the Wolffian duct and can result in urinary tract obstruction. This is often diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography showing bladder distention, hydronephrosis, oligohydramnios, and a fetus that is small for gestational age. In this patient who is premature, underweight, and has not voided, a midline mass is likely a distended bladder secondary to posterior urethral valves that were not diagnosed prenatally. Complications including rupture of a calyx around the kidney, or intraperitoneal bladder rupture. Definitive diagnosis of posterior urethral valves is made with voiding cystourethrography showing dilation, elongation, and tapering of the urethra. Treatment is with endoscopic valve ablation.

distractor_explanations.A: Alcohol toxicity in pregnancy can result in fetal alcohol syndrome, which can cause intellectual disability and congenital abnormalities such as microcephaly, facial abnormalities (eg, thin vermillion border, small palpebral fissures), and heart defects. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (Choice B) defines a variable state of disease related to adrenal hypofunction that results in decreased concentrations of cortisol with variable effects on mineralocorticoids and androgens. The presentation varies depending on the age of onset, severity, and gender of the patient. In rare, mild cases, infertility may be the only presenting complaint when declared in adolescence or young adulthood. Most cases of CAH are diagnosed in childhood. Meconium ileus (Choice C) occurs when abnormally thick meconium occludes the intestine, resulting in a bowel obstruction. It is associated with cystic fibrosis. This patient has already passed meconium. Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) (Choice D) is the most common renal malignancy in childhood resulting from mutations in tumor suppressor genes WT1 or WT2. It is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass and hematuria. Testicular torsion (Choice F) occurs when the testicle rotates about itself within the scrotal sac. The twisting of the spermatic cord, which contains the gonadal artery, pampiniform plexus, and gonadal vein results in vascular congestion and potential cessation of venous or arterial flow. This can lead to testicular infarction if not promptly managed.

explanation.educational_objective: Posterior urethral valves are formed from an abnormal remnant of the Wolffian duct and can result in urinary tract obstruction. Signs and symptoms can include bladder distention, hydronephrosis, oligohydramnios, and a fetus that is small for gestational age. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Posterior urethral valves are formed from an abnormal remnant of the Wolffian duct and can result in urinary tract obstruction. Signs and symptoms can include bladder distention, hydronephrosis, oligo

vignette.presentation:
24. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of increasing difficulty breathing . His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 36/min , and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg.
Examination shows jugular venous distention and mild swelling of the face and upper extremities . There are moderate intercostal retractions . lnspiratory and expiratory wheezes are heard bilaterally . An x-ray of the chest shows
a mass in the superior mediastinum and a large pleural effusion in the right hemithorax . Thoracentesis yields 400 ml of reddish brown serosanguineous fluid containing numerous erythrocytes . Which of the following is the most
likely cause of the pleural effusion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is most likely presenting with a malignant pleural effusion. His physical examination findings of jugular venous distention and edema of the face and upper extremities are suggestive of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, which is caused by obstruction of the SVC and venous congestion of the upper body and face. Obstruction of the SVC is often caused by extrinsic compression by a malignant mediastinal or pulmonary mass, which may be secondary to lung cancer, lymphoma, or metastatic disease from another primary source. Pleural effusions are clinically suspected on examination in the setting of dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds, and can be visualized on imaging including chest x-ray, CT scan, or ultrasonography. Analyzing the pleural fluid can show an underlying cause to guide therapy. Fluid is inspected for cell counts, organisms, pH, enzyme activity, and serum glucose concentration and total protein concentrations. Low pH and low serum glucose are indicative of increased cellular metabolism in the fluid and may indicate underlying malignancy and/or infection. Malignant pleural effusions may have increased erythrocyte counts or appear grossly hemorrhagic as a result of tumor invasion and disruption of blood vessels and the visceral pleura. As well, Light criteria assesses whether the pleural effusion is likely to be exudative (eg, complex fluid resulting from pneumonia, empyema, malignancy, or inflammatory disease) or transudative (eg, serous fluid resulting from imbalanced hydrostatic or oncotic pressures) through evaluating the concentrations of pleural fluid protein and lactate dehydrogenase.

distractor_explanations.A: Congestive heart failure and nephrotic syndrome (Choice C) may be complicated by transudative pleural effusions caused by volume overload. Pleural effusions associated with volume overload are most likely bilateral as a result of the underlying systemic derangement, while exudative effusions related to malignancy or infection are more commonly unilateral. As well, transudative effusions do not demonstrate increased erythrocyte, lactate dehydrogenase, or protein concentrations. Traumatic hemothorax (Choice D) is an exudative effusion that contains increased erythrocyte concentrations and may appear frankly bloody on thoracentesis. It often occurs in the setting of rib fractures and/or pulmonary contusions. Malignant pleural effusion is more likely in the setting of a mediastinal mass on imaging. Tuberculous pleural effusion (Choice E) may be seen in endemic regions in the setting of chronic tuberculosis infection. The pleural fluid is characteristically exudative, with a high lymphocyte count and an increased adenosine deaminase concentration.

explanation.educational_objective: Pleural effusions may be categorized as transudative or exudative based on the Light criteria. Increased protein or cells in the fluid indicates an exudative transfusion. Malignancy is a common cause of exudative pleural effusions, with lymphoma the most likely cause in a child with an underlying mediastinal mass. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Pleural effusions may be categorized as transudative or exudative based on the Light criteria. Increased protein or cells in the fluid indicates an exudative transfusion. Malignancy is a common cause

vignette.presentation:
25. An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of vomiting and drooling . She had been left alone in the bathroom of her home for a few minutes before the onset of the symptoms . The family
keeps nasal decongestants , acetaminophen , ibuprofen , diphenhydramine , drain cleaner , and insecticide spray in the bathroom . During the past 5 days , she has had an upper respiratory tract infection treated with a nasal
decongestant containing pseudoephedrine and acetaminophen . She is agitated and drooling . Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min , respirations are 26/min , and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows
two small superficial ulcers on the lips and tongue . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . The most likely cause of these findings is ingestion of which of the following?

question_stem: The most likely cause of these findings is ingestion of which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Drain cleaners are a common cause of caustic ingestions in children. They contain sodium and potassium hydroxides, alkali that are proton acceptors and strong nucleophiles. Alkali ingestion leads to liquefactive necrosis, lactic acidosis, and tissue penetration and ulceration. It can cause chemical burns and ulcerations of the tongue, airway, and esophagus, resulting in stridor, hoarseness, vomiting, and drooling. If severe, esophageal perforation can result leading to free air in the mediastinum. Treatment is initially focused on supportive measures including airway management and fluid resuscitation. Visible lesions in the oropharynx increase the likelihood of distal gastrointestinal lesions. Patients should be evaluated with endoscopy to assess for visceral injury. For severe injuries, treatment involves steroid administration.

distractor_explanations.A: Acetaminophen toxicity is characterized by acute liver failure. At high doses, saturation of phase II metabolic pathways leads to excess acetaminophen being metabolized by cytochrome P450-mediated reactions to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI), which has strong oxidizing properties and is directly hepatotoxic.
distractor_explanations.B: Diphenhydramine ingestion results in central nervous system H1-receptor blockade, anticholinergic, and anti-a-adrenergic side effects. This results in a constellation of symptoms such as dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, hallucinations, delirium, ataxia, flushed skin, visual disturbances (cycloplegia), and sedation.
distractor_explanations.D: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits cyclooxygenase. In small doses, it can cause impaired gastric mucosal protection resulting in gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. In large overdose or ingestion, ibuprofen can cause hypotension, hypothermia, and metabolic acidosis; however, this is uncommon.
distractor_explanations.E: Organophosphates are found in insecticides; exposure can occur transcutaneously, or via inhalation or ingestion. They are a cause of cholinergic excess as they inhibit acetylcholinesterase, which is characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, urination, diaphoresis, salivation, lacrimation, bronchorrhea, bronchospasm, bradycardia, seizures, and muscle weakness.
distractor_explanations.F: Pseudoephedrine is a sympathomimetic that activates the adrenergic receptor system and is used as an over-the-counter nasal decongestant because of its effects on nasal vasoconstriction. Ingestion and toxicity can cause nausea, vomiting, dizziness, headache, restlessness, and anxiety.

explanation.educational_objective: Drain cleaners contain caustic alkali that can cause burns and ulcerations of the tongue, airway, and esophagus, resulting in stridor, hoarseness, vomiting, and drooling. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Drain cleaners contain caustic alkali that can cause burns and ulcerations of the tongue, airway, and esophagus, resulting in stridor, hoarseness, vomiting, and drooling. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
26. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of left hip pain for 2 days and an associated limp for the past 4 hours. One week ago , he had watery stools and temperatures to 37.8°C (100°F);
these symptoms resolved within 2 days . There is no history of trauma or recent immunizations . He is otherwise healthy, and his immunizations are up-to-date . He appears alert . His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F) , pulse is 90/min ,
respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. The left hip is not swollen or erythematous , but there is pain with movement and weight bearing . His erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 28 mm/h . Ultrasonography of
the left hip joint shows a small effusion . Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this otherwise healthy patient is transient synovitis of the hip. Transient synovitis is an inflammatory condition involving the synovial lining of weight-bearing joints, with the hip being commonly affected. It classically presents in children recovering from a viral infection with pain on weight-bearing, antalgic gait, refusal to ambulate, tenderness over the joint, and pain elicited with range of motion. Vital signs are generally within normal limits, as are laboratory studies with the exception of increased markers of inflammation such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Antecedent viral infection has been reported in up to 30% of cases of transient synovitis. Diagnosis involves the exclusion of emergent or urgent conditions such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture. Treatment is supportive, and involves rest plus nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, making oral ibuprofen the best choice for this patient. If there is diagnostic uncertainty, arthrocentesis to exclude septic arthritis, along with imaging to assess for osteomyelitis or fracture should be conducted.

distractor_explanations.A: Oral acyclovir is appropriate for cases of herpetic infections, such as herpes labial is, genital herpes, or varicella infections. Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that must first be activated by viral thymidine kinase, and ultimately prevents replication of the viral genome. It demonstrates no independent anti-inflammatory properties. Oral clindamycin (Choice B), an antibiotic that inhibits the 50S ribosomal subunit, is appropriate for treating cases of skin and soft-tissue infections, and exhibits broad activity against many gram-positive, gram negative, and anaerobic pathogens. Intravenous ceftriaxone (Choice D) and intravenous vancomycin (Choice E) are appropriate for the inpatient treatment of bacterial infections and are a common empiric regimen used to treat meningitis. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, has a broad spectrum of activity against gram-positive and gram-negative organisms, including Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of migratory polyarthritis. Vancomycin inhibits the synthesis of bacterial cell walls, and therefore has the greatest activity against gram-positive organisms. It would be an appropriate choice to treat osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, or skin and soft-tissue infections caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

explanation.educational_objective: Transient synovitis is a noninfectious arthropathy that presents with pain of weight-bearing joints, often the hip, frequently following a viral infection in a child. Diagnosis involves the exclusion of emergent or urgent conditions such as cellulitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and fracture. It is best managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Transient synovitis is a noninfectious arthropathy that presents with pain of weight-bearing joints, often the hip, frequently following a viral infection in a child. Diagnosis involves the exclusion

vignette.presentation:
27. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician for an evaluation of short stature and delayed puberty . She has never had a menstrual period . Since birth , the patient's height has been below the 3rd percentile , and her weight has
been at the 3rd percentile . At the age of 10 years , x-rays of the left hand and wrist showed that bone age was equal to chronologic age . Her mother, who is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall , had menarche at the age of 12 years . Her father
is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall. The patient is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m 2 Her pulse is 76/min , and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple nevi over the face and trunk .
•
There is bilateral pedal edema . Breast development is Tanner stage 1, and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gonadal dysgenesis 45, X (Turner syndrome) results from monosomy of the X chromosome and presents with characteristic physical features including short stature, a wide webbed neck, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and multiple melanocytic nevi. Short stature in patients with Turner syndrome likely results from haploinsufficiency of the short stature homeobox gene on the X chromosome. Delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics is common, such as with the Tanner Stage 1 breast and pubic hair development in this patient. Primary amenorrhea is also a common finding. Patients with Turner syndrome may also present with bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation, or a fused kidney.

distractor_explanations.A: may occur in pediatric patients and more commonly presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism. Thyroid dysfunction is less likely to result in delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics. Constitutional short stature (Choice B) may lead to short stature during childhood and adolescence but usually results in normal adult stature. This diagnosis would not account for the patient's finding of primary amenorrhea and delayed sexual development.
distractor_explanations.C: Craniopharyngioma may lead to acquired deficiency of growth hormone. However, other accompanying findings are usually encountered, such as headache, vomiting, and visual field defects. Familial short stature (Choice D) is a common cause of short stature, but the child's expected height should be relatively similar to that of her parents. This child is both significantly shorter than both parents and has other findings, such as primary amenorrhea and delayed sexual development that would not be explained by this diagnosis. Idiopathic hypopituitarism (Choice F) may result in deficiency of one or several pituitary hormones, but it is a diagnosis requiring laboratory investigation and would not present with the remaining characteristic physical examination findings of Turner syndrome.

explanation.educational_objective: Gonadal dysgenesis 45, X (Turner syndrome) results from monosomy of the X chromosome and presents with characteristic physical features including short stature, a wide webbed neck, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, multiple melanocytic nevi, primary amenorrhea, and delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics. Short stature in patients with Turner syndrome likely results from haploinsufficiency of the short stature homeobox gene on the X chromosome. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Gonadal dysgenesis 45, X (Turner syndrome) results from monosomy of the X chromosome and presents with characteristic physical features including short stature, a wide webbed neck, a broad chest with

vignette.presentation:
28. A 3-year-old boy is brought for a well-child examination . His mother states that his belly seems big. His vital signs are within normal limits . Examination shows aniridia . There is a palpable mass in the right flank . The remainder of
the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of urine vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nephroblastoma, or Wilms tumor, is the most common renal malignancy in childhood as a result of mutations in tumor suppressor genes WT1 or WT2. It is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass. Patients can be asymptomatic or have symptoms of abdominal pain or hematuria. Nephroblastoma can also be associated with congenital anomalies such as hemihypertrophy, genitourinary abnormalities, and aniridia. The preferred initial diagnostic study is typically abdominal ultrasonography to evaluate the abdominal mass. Other masses that can be differentiated from nephroblastoma include hydronephrosis and polycystic kidney disease. If nephroblastoma is diagnosed, further imaging can be done to further evaluate any tumor infiltration and the full extent of the mass.

distractor_explanations.A: Measurement of serum catecholamine concentration can be performed in the evaluation of pheochromocytoma or neuroblastoma. Measurement of urine vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid concentrations (Choice B) is also performed in the evaluation of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, tremors, agitation, tachycardia, tachypnea, and treatment-refractory hypertension. It is a common tumor of the adrenal medulla and is marked by the functional secretion of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, which cause episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms. X-ray of the abdomen (Choice C) can be performed to evaluate for bowel obstruction, swallowed foreign body, necrotizing enterocolitis, or constipation. An x-ray is not as sensitive as a CT scan and has little utility in the evaluation of abdominal masses. Chest imaging can elucidate whether there are any lung metastases. An x-ray of the chest (Choice D) would be less sensitive for this purpose, and the abdominal mass should be first evaluated.

explanation.educational_objective: Nephroblastoma is the most common pediatric renal malignancy and is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass. The preferred initial diagnostic study is typically abdominal ultrasonography to evaluate the mass. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Nephroblastoma is the most common pediatric renal malignancy and is characterized by a large, often palpable, unilateral flank mass. The preferred initial diagnostic study is typically abdominal ultra

vignette.presentation:
29. An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of lethargy, mild abdominal pain, and dark urine . He had a sore throat and an upper respiratory tract infection 10 days ago that resolved spontaneously .
His pulse is 90/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows slight swelling around the eyes . Urinalysis shows light brown urine with RBC and granular casts . Which of the following is
the most likely mechanism for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism for these findings?

choices.text: Bacterial infiltration of the basement membrane
Bacterial infiltration of the epithelial cells

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of nephritic syndrome characterized by peripheral and periorbital edema, dark-colored urine, hypertension, acute kidney injury, and proteinuria following an infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A). The pathogenesis of PSGN involves streptococcal antigens complexing with antibodies, deposition of immune complexes in the glomerular basement membrane, and subsequent complement activation and inflammation. Neutrophilic infiltration of the glomerular tuft can be seen in PSGN. Management of PSGN is supportive and focused on treating complications such as volume overload and hypertension with diuretics and antihypertensive medications. Rarely, severe kidney injury secondary to PSGN may require kidney replacement therapy.

distractor_explanations.D: Destruction of tubular epithelial cells describes the pathophysiology of acute tubular necrosis. Acute tubular necrosis typically occurs following an ischemic (Choice E) or nephrotoxic insult to the kidneys, which results in necrosis of the tubular epithelium. Granular, muddy brown casts are typical on urinalysis.

explanation.educational_objective: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a nephritic syndrome characterized by peripheral and periorbital edema, dark-colored urine, hypertension, acute kidney injury, and proteinuria following an infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A). The pathogenesis of PSGN involves streptococcal antigens complexing with antibodies, deposition of immune complexes in the glomerular basement membrane, and subsequent complement activation and inflammation. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
30. A 2370-g (5-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old primigravid woman who had limited prenatal care . The mother drank one to two beers daily but did not use any illicit drugs . The newborn appears vigorous and is
not cyanotic . Examination shows a prominent occiput , narrow palpebral fissures , a small recessed mandible , and a short sternum . The hands are clenched with the index finger folded over the middle finger and the small finger
folded over the ring finger . There is a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the lower left sternal border . The abdomen is prominent and soft ; there is no hepatosplenomegaly . Peripheral pulses are normal. There is
generalized hypertonia . Deep tendon reflexes are present. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this newborn's low birth weight?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this newborn's low birth weight?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lntussusception occurs when a segment of bowel telescopes into an adjacent segment, resulting in colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and potential bloody, mucoid stools. Classically, it presents in an infant or young child with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain often punctuated by asymptomatic periods. lntussusception typically occurs as a result of the presence of a pathologic lead point, often lymphoid hyperplasia, lymphadenopathy, Meckel diverticulum, stricture, or malignancy, which acts to draw one segment of bowel into an adjacent segment during peristalsis. If the intussusception self-resolves, there may be no symptoms. If it does not resolve, traction on mesenteric vessels can result in hypoperfusion of the segment with resultant inflammation, hemorrhage, obstruction, and pain. It may be detected on physical examination as an elongated mass, often in the right upper quadrant. Diagnosis consists of clinical history and physical examination and is supported by imaging. Ultrasonography evaluation is preferred in young children and will show telescoping interposed bowel segments in longitudinal orientation or a targetoid appearance in transverse orientation. Treatment of an ileocolic intussusception requires the administration of a contrast enema, which decreases the intussusception. Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this setting. Surgery may be required in cases where there is repetitive failure of the enema to decrease the intussusception or if the patient presents with symptoms concerning for bowel necrosis or perforation.

distractor_explanations.A: Arthrogryposis describes congenital joint contractures, which result in impaired joint movement and function and may lead to muscle atrophy. Congenital infection (Choice B) can occur with multiple viruses such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), herpes simplex virus (HSV), rubella, measles, or parvovirus. Each congenital viral infection results in different congenital abnormalities. HSV can cause both cutaneous herpetic lesions and systemic manifestations like meningoencephalitis. Congenital infection with CMV manifests as hearing loss, seizures, a petechial rash, intracranial calcifications, organomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Neonates with congenital rubella infection exhibit a classic triad of cataracts, sensorineural deafness, and congenital heart disease. Exposure to alcohol in utero (Choice C) results in fetal alcohol syndrome, which can cause intellectual disability and congenital abnormalities such as microcephaly, facial abnormalities (eg, thin vermillion border, small palpebral fissures), and heart defects. Uteroplacental insufficiency (Choice E) describes insufficient blood flow to the placenta, abnormal placenta, or inability of the placenta to deliver sufficient nutrients to the fetus during pregnancy. It can result in a variety of disorders including fetal hypoglycemia, oligohydramnios, intrauterine growth restriction, or maternal complications including preeclampsia, miscarriage, or stillbirth.

explanation.educational_objective: Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, presents with characteristic physical features including intellectual disability, a prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, clenched overlapping fingers, and feet with prominent calcanei and convexly rounded soles. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, presents with characteristic physical features including intellectual disability, a prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, clenched overlapping fing

vignette.presentation:
32. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he is concerned that he has not had to begin shaving . He says all of his friends have begun shaving . He first noticed pubic hair development 6 months ago . He is at the 25th
percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Examination shows mild bilateral gynecomastia . Genital and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities .
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Puberty in boys typically follows a predictable course of gonadarche (enlargement of the testes), followed by pubarche (pubic hair), followed by adrenarche (axillary hair, facial hair, voice changes), followed by a growth spurt. This differs from the process in girls, which proceeds from thelarche (breast buds) to pubarche to growth spurt and finally menarche. In boys, delayed puberty is defined as the absence of testicular enlargement or secondary sexual characteristics at the age of 14 years. The most common cause of delayed puberty is constitutional delay of growth and puberty (CDGP), accounting for approximately 50% of cases, a normal variant. In CDGP, there is a transient defect in the production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone with resultant delay in the stimulation of pituitary production of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone. CDGP tends to be familial with many members of the same family undergoing late puberty compared with peers. In this case, the patient has undergone gonadarche (indicated by his Tanner stage 2 genital development) and pubarche but has not yet undergone adrenarche. Thus, while delayed, the sequence of his procession through the steps of puberty is appropriate and he can be reassured that his development will continue to progress.

distractor_explanations.B: Measurement of serum testosterone concentration is unnecessary in this case because the patient is progressing through the stages of puberty as expected. If his puberty did not continue to progress, testosterone measurement could be used to differentiate CDGP from another pathology. Mild bilateral gynecomastia can be normal in early puberty as a result of the small increase in extragonadal production of estrogen relative to the amount of testosterone being produced. Urine toxicology screening (Choice C) would be appropriate if there was a suspicion for drug use inducing gynecomastia, of which marijuana is the most common recreational drug. Breast biopsy (Choice E) would be indicated if the breast enlargement was caused by a nodule or mass rather than true gynecomastia. If delayed puberty were accompanied by neurologic findings or suspected to be caused by a process involving the brain such as a pituitary adenoma, MRI of the brain, not CT scan of the head (Choice D), would be indicated. Neither imaging modality is necessary in this case.

explanation.educational_objective: In boys, puberty follows a predictable course of gonadarche, pubarche, and growth spurt. Delayed puberty is defined as the absence of testicular enlargement or secondary sexual characteristics at the age of 14 years and is most commonly caused by constitutional delay of growth and puberty. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: In boys, puberty follows a predictable course of gonadarche, pubarche, and growth spurt. Delayed puberty is defined as the absence of testicular enlargement or secondary sexual characteristics at the

vignette.presentation:
33. A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of mild itching of his head and scattered areas of hair loss on his scalp . Examination shows several small oval areas of alopecia over
the posterior scalp with numerous hairs broken off close to the scalp . Several small , occipital , nontender lymph nodes are palpated . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most
likely causal organism?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that is common in children. It presents as scaly patches with alopecia, patches of alopecia with black dots that represent broken hairs, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The most common causal organism is Trichophyton tonsurans, although infections can also be caused by other Trichophyton species, Microsporum species, and Epidermophyton species. A potassium hydroxide preparation of a skin scraping will show fungal hyphae or spores. It is treated with oral antifungals, such as griseofulvin or terbinafine.

distractor_explanations.A: Candida albicans can cause a variety of infections, such as oral thrush, esophagitis, and vulvovaginal candidiasis. It can also cause systemic infections in immunocompromised patients. It does not cause tinea capitis. Epidermophyton floccosum (Choice B) is a dermatophyte that can cause skin and nail infections, such as tinea pedis and tinea corporis. It less commonly causes tinea capitis. Ma/assezia furfur (Choice C) causes tinea versicolor, a superficial fungal infection of the skin that commonly presents with areas of hypopigmentation, hyperpigmentation, or macules on the trunk and proximal upper extremities. It does not cause tinea capitis. Microsporum audouinii (Choice D) is a dermatophyte that causes skin infections, such as tinea capitis and tinea corporis. However, it is a less common causal pathogen than Trichophyton tonsurans in tinea capitis.

explanation.educational_objective: Tinea capitis presents commonly in children with scaly patches, hair loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A frequent causal organism is Trichophyton tonsurans. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Tinea capitis presents commonly in children with scaly patches, hair loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A frequent causal organism is Trichophyton tonsurans. r " , r-- r ,

34. A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of chickenpox for 4 weeks . She developed vesicular lesions on her head , trunk , and extremities 2 weeks after her older brother developed lesions , and she has continued
to have new lesions since then . She is at the 10th percentile for length , weight , and head circumference . Her temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F). Examination shows pa pules , fluid-filled vesicles , and crusted small ulcers scattered
over the head , trunk , and proximal extremities . Indirect fluorescent antibody testing of the material from the base of one of the vesicles is positive for the varicella antigen . Which of the following is the most likely immunologic
abnormality?

question_stem:
the most likely immunologic
abnormality?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Varicella zoster, also known as human herpesvirus-3, is transmitted via respiratory secretions and direct contact with infected skin lesions. It causes the disease chickenpox in immunocompetent children and can cause encephalitis and pneumonia in immunosuppressed children. The rash associated with chickenpox typically persists for 1 to 2 weeks. Varicella is uncommon in infancy and may occur as an opportunistic infection in infants with HIV or as an immunocompromising condition impairing T lymphocytes. As with many viral infections, T lymphocyte function is an essential component of host defense and is impaired in the setting of HIV infection. Persistence of symptoms for 1 month is suggestive of underlying T-lymphocyte immunodeficiency. Infants with immunodeficiency are at a greater risk for severe consequences of varicella infection, including end organ involvement.

distractor_explanations.A: lymphocyte function occurs in several immunodeficiencies such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency. Affected infants demonstrate recurrent infections with both bacterial and viral organisms. Impaired complement function (Choice B) occurs in several complement disorders. Patients with deficient function of complement are at increased risk for infection with encapsulated bacterial organisms. Impaired neutrophil adhesion (Choice C) occurs in leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Patients present with recurrent skin and mucosal infections, absent pus, and delayed separation of the umbilical cord. Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis (Choice D) occurs in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which presents with albinism, peripheral neuropathy, and recurrent pyogenic infections. Neutrophil oxidation burst (Choice F) defects occur in chronic granulomatous disease, which presents with recurrent infections with organisms possessing catalase, such as Staphylococcus aureus.

explanation.educational_objective: Defense against varicella zoster virus relies on T lymphocyte function, which is impaired in the setting of HIV infection and T-lymphocyte immunodeficiency. Infants with deficient T lymphocyte function are at an increased risk for severe infection with varicella, which may manifest as persistent infection or end organ involvement. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Defense against varicella zoster virus relies on T lymphocyte function, which is impaired in the setting of HIV infection and T-lymphocyte immunodeficiency. Infants with deficient T lymphocyte functio

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: DiGeorge syndrome is a disorder caused by a microdeletion in the 22q11.2 chromosome, which results in abnormal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. It presents early in childhood with thymic hypoplasia and impaired immunity, conotruncal cardiac defects (eg, truncus arteriosus), hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hypoplasia, and craniofacial abnormalities, such as low set ears, hypertelorism, micrognathia, and cleft lip and palate. It is associated with developmental delay. Laboratory evaluation will show leukopenia and decreased calcium concentrations, while a chest x-ray may demonstrate the absence of a thymic shadow, as in this patient. Further evaluation typically includes an echocardiography and kidney ultrasonography. Treatment is supportive. This patient presenting with jitteriness in the setting of hypocalcemia and truncus arteriosus likely has DiGeorge syndrome, making hypoparathyroidism the most likely diagnosis. Severe hypocalcemia can also present with seizures, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, and emesis.

distractor_explanations.A: , when primary, presents with hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia, most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma, and less likely hyperplasia or carcinoma. Hypercalcemia presents with abdominal pain, nephrolithiasis, bone pain, and altered mental status. Secondary hyperparathyroidism presents with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, but this usually occurs in the setting of chronic kidney disease. Pseudohypoparathyroidism {
distractor_explanations.C: is caused by an impaired response of the kidney to parathyroid hormone, which results in hypocalcemia. It is commonly associated with short stature, developmental delay, and osteodystrophy as part of a genetic disorder referred to as Albright hereditary osteodystrophy. It is not associated with cardiac defects. Renal proximal tubular dysfunction {
distractor_explanations.D: commonly causes a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis as a result of an inability to reabsorb sodium bicarbonate. It can be a symptom of Fanconi syndrome, which also presents with hypophosphatemic rickets and growth delay. Vitamin D-deficient rickets {
distractor_explanations.E: presents with hypocalcemia and bone weakening that can lead to deformities such as genu varum. It is usually secondary to a prolonged deficiency of Vitamin D and would not be expected to present at birth. X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets {
distractor_explanations.F: is caused by an inherited inability of the renal proximal tubule to reabsorb phosphate and presents similarly to vitamin D-deficient rickets. It would not be expected to cause such a severe decrease in blood calcium concentrations.

explanation.educational_objective: DiGeorge syndrome presents with thymic hypoplasia and impaired immunity, conotruncal cardiac defects, hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hypoplasia, and craniofacial abnormalities. Parathyroid hypoplasia can lead to severe hypocalcemia after birth, with symptoms of neuromuscular instability and, occasional
explanation.concept: DiGeorge syndrome presents with thymic hypoplasia and impaired immunity, conotruncal cardiac defects, hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hypoplasia, and craniofacial abnormalities. Parathyroid hypopla

vignette.presentation:
37. A 9-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy, labored breathing , and seven episodes of vomiting over the past 6 hours. Her skin is flushed and warm and she
appears severely dehydrated . There is a fruity odor to her breath. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min , and blood
pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is 4 seconds , and capillary blood glucose concentration is greater than 500 mg/dl . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of 5% dextrose in water
Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of 0.9% saline
Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of lactated Ringer solution with 40 mEq/L of potassium chloride
Intravenous administration of 0.1 U/h of regular insulin
Continuous intravenous administration of 0.1 U/h of regular insulin

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) occurs as a result of the accumulation of serum ketones such as ~-hydroxybutyric acid, acetoacetic acid, and acetone in the setting of deficient insulin signaling. Dysregulated fatty acid degradation and ketone synthesis occurs as a result of the relative state of starvation created through absent insulin signaling. Extracellular hyperglycemia creates an osmotic effect resulting in the shift of fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space with accompanying profuse osmotic diuresis and intracellular volume loss. Patients present with signs and symptoms including tachycardia, tachypnea, fatigue, polyuria, shortness of breath, Kussmaul respiration, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Laboratory evaluation typically shows increased concentrations of glucose, ketones, and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis caused by the accumulation of unmeasured anions (ketones, lactic acid) in serum. Treatment is through the replacement of insulin, volume repletion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and treatment of any precipitating conditions. Insulin is typically repleted at an initial dose of 0.1 U/kg/hour by intravenous infusion. Volume resuscitation with 0.9% saline is essential to restore intracellular fluid volume and lower the extracellular glucose concentration and is the initial step in the management of DKA even prior to insulin administration. Administering insulin prior to knowing the serum potassium concentration can result in life-threatening hypokalemia.

distractor_explanations.A: dextrose in water would worsen this patient's profound hyperglycemia. 0.9% saline is a more appropriate initial resuscitation fluid. Intravenous administration of 20 ml/kg of lactated Ringer solution with 40 mEq/L of potassium chloride (Choice C) may be acceptable once the patient's potassium concentration is known; however, in DKA, derangements in potassium can include hypo- or hyperkalemia. Infusing a fluid with potassium may result in worsening of unknown derangements with potentially life-threatening dysrhythmias. Administration of regular insulin either via intravenous dose at 0.1 U/h (Choice D) or via continuous intravenous infusion at 0.1 U/h (Choice E) is not the best next step because neither of these options are adjusted for the patient's weight. Insulin is typically repleted at an initial dose of 0.1 U/kg/h by intravenous infusion. Intravenous volume repletion with 0.9% saline is therefore a more appropriate initial step. Additionally, insulin repletion is only appropriate in DKA once the serum potassium concentration is known to prevent precipitating life-threatening derangements in potassium.

explanation.educational_objective: Extracellular hyperglycemia in the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis creates an osmotic effect resulting in the shift of fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space with accompanying diuresis and intracellular volume loss. Restoration of fluid balance is an essential step in the emergent management of diabetic ketoacidosis and is best accomplished with the intravenous administration of 0.9% saline. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Extracellular hyperglycemia in the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis creates an osmotic effect resulting in the shift of fluid from the intracellular to the extracellular space with accompanying diures

her abdomen , back , and lower extremities . Her temperature is 38.9°C(102 .1 °F), pulse is 100/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a diffuse red , macular and papular rash
involving the face , trunk , and extremities ; there are no lesions on the palms or soles . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Ehrlichiosis F) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Pityriasis rosea J) Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome
Ehrlichiosis F) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Measles (rubeola) virus is a highly contagious paramyxovirus that causes the disease measles, which is associated with acute febrile illness and potentially severe sequelae. It is more common in children than adults. It characteristically presents with a prodromal fever along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a confluent maculopapular rash that starts at the head/neck and spreads to the trunk, excluding the palms and soles. Physical examination may show bright red macules with a bluish-white center on the buccal mucosa (Koplik spots) and lymphadenopathy. Treatment is supportive. Vitamin A deficiency is associated with severe disease and complications, and supplementation should be provided, especially in children who are malnourished. Complications of measles include subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (a neurodegenerative disease associated with intellectual regression, personality changes, motor deterioration, seizures, and premature death), encephalitis, and giant cell pneumonia.

distractor_explanations.A: arAntitrypsin deficiency results in the early development of panacinar emphysema and cirrhosis. It is a hereditary disease resulting from misfolding of arantitrypsin. The lack of functional arantitrypsin release results in an imbalance of proteases and antiproteases in the lung parenchyma, resulting in the destruction of alveolar septa and development of panacinar emphysema.
distractor_explanations.B: Asthma is characterized by reversible obstruction to airflow caused by the spasm of smooth muscle in the bronchi and small airways, and may present with dyspnea, wheezing, or chronic nonproductive cough. It is often triggered by an allergen (eg, smoke, pollen), exercise, or temperature change. It may be associated with progressive reactive airway remodeling over time. The lack of response to inhaled 13- adrenergic agonists and oral prednisone in this patient do not support the diagnosis of asthma. Congenital emphysema (Choice D) is a rare pulmonary disorder caused by disrupted embryonic bronchopulmonary development and is characterized by air trapping and lung hyperinflation, which can be visualized on chest imaging. The severity of disease varies widely and may be asymptomatic until adulthood or present in the newborn with respiratory distress. Cystic fibrosis (Choice E) is a clinical syndrome resulting from defects in the CFTR gene, leading to a deficiency in a chloride channel that secretes chloride in the lungs and gastrointestinal tract and reabsorbs chloride in sweat glands. Cystic fibrosis is associated with bronchiectasis because of the risk for recurrent pulmonary infections. The absence of other findings associated with cystic fibrosis, such as pancreatic insufficiency, diarrhea, malnutrition, and weight loss, argue against cystic fibrosis as the cause of this patient's bronchiectasis.

explanation.educational_objective: Rubeola is caused by the measles paramyxovirus and presents with an acute febrile illness accompanied by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a confluent maculopapular rash that starts at the head/neck and spreads to the trunk, excluding the palms and soles. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Rubeola is caused by the measles paramyxovirus and presents with an acute febrile illness accompanied by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a confluent maculopapular rash that starts at the head/neck

delivery and weighed 2608 g {5 lb 12 oz). The newborn's blood group is 0 , Rh-positive , and the mother's blood group is B, Rh-positive . He has been breast-fed since birth and receives 1 to 2 ounces of a supplemental
soy milk-based formula every day. His mother says that he has had about seven wet diapers daily, and his stools are yellow and seedy. At discharge 2 days ago , his weight was 2495 g (5 lb 8 oz); he now weighs
2608 g (5 lb 12 oz). His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F) , pulse is 138/min, respirations are 32/min , and blood pressure is 65/40 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice from the face to the lower abdomen . The
liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies at 36 hours of age and now show:
At 36 Hours of Age Now
Hematocrit (%) 54 52
Serum
Bilirubin , total (mg/dl) 8.2 12.5
Direct (mg/dl) 0.1 0.3
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus
Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus
Measurement of serum angiotensin-converting enzyme activity
Measurement of serum C1 esterase inhibitor concentration
Culture of the pharynx for bacteria

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal jaundice is defined as an increased bilirubin concentration (greater than 5 mg/dl), which results from either increased hemolysis {bilirubin generation) or decreased bilirubin conjugation or excretion. Hyperbilirubinemia can be divided into direct and indirect forms in which either conjugated or unconjugated bilirubin accumulate, respectively. It can also be divided into physiologic and pathologic forms. Features of physiologic jaundice include development after 24 hours of life, a rate of bilirubin rise of less than 0.5 mg/dl daily, a maximum peak of 14 to 15 mg/dl, and a predominance of indirect bilirubin (greater than 90%). In contrast, jaundice within the first 24 hours of life {which rises faster than 0.5 mg/dl per hour), a predominance of direct bilirubin, and persistence beyond 2 weeks would suggest a pathologic cause. Newborn physiologic jaundice, also termed benign neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, occurs in nearly all newborns and is caused by the increased breakdown of red blood cells and thus generation of bilirubin, the immature liver metabolism of bilirubin, and the increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. These features taken together cause an indirect hyperbilirubinemia to develop. Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia is closely monitored in order to prevent kernicterus, which refers to the deposition of bilirubin in the basal ganglia, pons, and cerebellum. This can occur at bilirubin concentrations of 25 to 30 mg/dl. Treatment of the underlying cause of the jaundice and phototherapy for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia or exchange transfusion prevents this potentially fatal consequence. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, C, D, and F. ABO isoimmunization {Choice A) occurs when maternal lgG antibodies to fetal red blood cell antigens cause either fetal or neonatal destruction of these red blood cells. Bilirubin production is increased, and an indirect hyperbilirubinemia ensues. This cause of neonatal jaundice will present with pathologic findings such as an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, neither of which are present in this case. Biliary obstruction {Choice B) caused by biliary atresia is a common cause of direct hyperbilirubinemia. In congenital biliary atresia, the common bile duct is occluded or atretic and bile is unable to pass into the duodenum. Dehydration {Choice C) is the mechanism behind breastfeeding jaundice. In the first week of life, as a breastfeeding mother's milk begins to establish, the infant may become dehydrated. Dehydration leads to increased enterohepatic circulation and reabsorption of bilirubin, resulting in indirect hyperbilirubinemia. In this case, the infant's consistent wet diapers and stools argue against a dehydrated state. Erythrocyte enzyme defect {Choice D) such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes increased hemolysis of red blood cells and a subsequent increase in unconjugated bilirubin. This cause of ., 11 • ,e I 1 I .. 1 •., I• •1., II .. 11 .. ti .. • I • .. Ill 1 1 .. I .,1 .. t• •,.•I 1• 1•,11 I .. This cause of neonatal jaundice will present with pathologic findings such as an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, neither of which are present in this case. This cause of neonatal jaundice would present with an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, along with a substantial decrease in the newborn's hematocrit.
