explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cyclic neutropenia is a rare inherited immunodeficiency syndrome characterized by periodic episodes of neutropenia and infection. Most cases follow a cyclic pattern that reoccurs every 21 days and typically lasts for 3 to 6 days. Classic symptoms include fever, malaise, and ulcers affecting the oral mucous membranes. Some patients may also develop pharyngitis and chronic periodontal disease that can result in early tooth loss. During episodes of neutropenia, patients are at increased risk for bacterial infections that may involve the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, urinary tract, or skin. The pathophysiology is not well understood, however, the disease is associated with mutations in the gene encoding neutrophil elastase. The diagnosis can be confirmed by monitoring a patient's neutrophil count several times weekly for at least 6 weeks. Genetic testing for mutations in the neutrophil elastase gene is also recommended. Acute management involves treatment of the current infection with appropriate therapies and maintaining good oral/dental hygiene. Long-term therapy with human granulocyte-colony stimulating factor is effective in keeping neutrophils at normal concentrations in the blood.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This newborn presents with findings consistent with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV, also known as human herpesvirus 5, belongs to the family of herpesviruses, and possesses a large, double-stranded DNA genome. Pregnant women most often contract CMV through exposure from young children, often through daycare centers. A primary maternal infection has a high risk for vertical transmission via the placenta to the fetus. Congenital CMV infection presents with intrauterine growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial calcifications, hearing loss, seizures, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and petechial rash. Congenital CMV infection is the most common cause of nonhereditary sensorineural hearing loss. In about 10% of cases, hearing loss may be an isolated finding without other symptoms of infection present. Hearing loss is also the most common sequela of an initially asymptomatic newborn. Fetal hydrops is a potential complication of CMV infection, although less common than in the setting of congenital parvovirus B19 infection. Intracranial calcifications have a characteristic periventricular distribution and may be detected by ultrasonography or CT scan. The diagnosis is confirmed with viral culture or polymerase chain amplification from urine or blood within the first week of life. Treatment is with antiviral agents such as ganciclovir or valganciclovir.

9. A3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pale complexion, low-grade fever, vomiting, occasional diarrhea, fl
and poor feeding. On arrival, he appears mildly dehydrated and cyanotic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 35/min, and
blood pressure is 80/48 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. A grade 3/6, harsh systolic ejection murmur is heard over
the entire precordium. Perfusion and muscle tone are normal. During attempts to insert an intravenous catheter, the patient begins to cry and becomes
agitated. His oxygen saturation decreases to 60%, and the murmur becomes barely audible. Supplemental oxygen is administered. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tetralogy of Fallot is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with paroxysmal cyanosis during crying spells and a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur on examination. Tetralogy of Fallot consists of pulmonary infundibular stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect (VSD), and right ventricular hypertrophy, resulting in a right- to-left shunt with cyanosis first noted in infancy. Right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction eventually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy. The murmur heard with Tetralogy of Fallot, which is typically a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border, is caused by RVOT obstruction, not as often by the VSD. Paroxysmal cyanosis that occurs during periods of crying is a classic presentation and these episodes are referred to as “tet” spells. Patients during one of these spells often exhibit rapid, deep breathing, agitation, and progressive cyanosis. These periods of cyanosis occur as a result of transient obstruction or occlusion of the RVOT leading to decreased blood flow through the pulmonary circulation, although the cause of the underlying transient obstruction is unclear. Treatment of tetralogy of Fallot is with surgical correction. Surgery aims to relieve the RVOT obstruction, close the VSD, and separate the pulmonary and systemic circulation. Surgery is usually performed in the first 6 months of life and almost always within the first year. . 4 > @ ° + — @ € > o  Bg

distractor_explanations.A: is a common congenital malformation of the interatrial septum that results in a left-to-right shunt between the atria. Mixing of oxygenated blood from the left atrium with deoxygenated blood returning from the superior vena cava results in higher oxygen concentration in the right atrium and ventricle than normal. It does not cause cyanosis. It is associated with a fixed split-second heart sound on cardiac auscultation. Coarctation of the aorta (
distractor_explanations.B: often presents in childhood with hypertension in an upper extremity and a systolic murmur. It is associated with weak lower extremity pulses and differentially lower blood pressure in the lower extremities. lsolated pulmonary stenosis (
distractor_explanations.C: is typically a benign, congenital heart defect when found in children and not associated with another congenital heart syndrome, such as tetralogy of Fallot or Noonan syndrome. Ventricular septal defect (
distractor_explanations.E: refers to a defect in the interventricular septum, most commonly the membranous portion. It is characterized by a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border. It does not cause cyanosis.

Patients present with “tet” spells that occur as a result of transient obstruction of the RVOT leading to cyanosis. vignette.presentation:
10. A5-day-old boy of Mediterranean descent is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of progressive jaundice. He has had five yellow, seedy

stools daily during this period. He was born at term to a 32-year-old primigravid woman. During the third trimester, his mother took an old prescription of

sulfamethoxazole for cystitis without consulting the physician. The blood group of the mother and the newborn is O, Rh-positive. He receives 2 ounces of a

cow's milk-based formula every 2 hours. Examination shows no abnormalities except for jaundice from the head to the upper thighs. His hematocrit is 33%,

and total serum bilirubin concentration is 20 mg/dL with a direct component of 0.9 mg/dL. Direct and indirect antiglobulin (Coombs) tests are negative.

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's jaundice?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's jaundice?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal jaundice is defined as an increased bilirubin (>5 mg/dL) that results from either increased hemolysis (bilirubin generation) or decreased bilirubin conjugation or excretion. Hyperbilirubinemia can be divided into direct and indirect forms in which either conjugated or unconjugated bilirubin accumulate, respectively. It can also be divided into physiologic and pathologic forms. This patient has anemia and an indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia that has presented in the first few days of life, suggesting a pathologic hemolytic process. The differential includes immune-mediated hemolysis, inherited erythrocyte membrane defects, and erythrocyte enzyme deficiencies. For this patient with a negative Coombs test and Mediterranean background, the most likely cause of his unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). G6PD is an enzyme in erythrocytes that makes NADPH from NADP+. An inadequate supply of NADPH leads to decreased concentrations of glutathione, which is a critical scavenger of reactive oxygen species within erythrocytes. Increased oxidative stress, which can occur with exposure to sulfa-containing compounds, results in hemolysis. . 4 e @ + — @ € > o  =

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a defect in the androgen receptor complex resulting in a genotypic 46,XY person developing phenotypic female or ul atypical genitalia and female secondary sexual characteristics. Testes are present and produce testosterone normally, but the absence of a functioning androgen im receptor prevents hormone binding and thereby prevents the development of secondary male sexual characteristics. Patients present with female external genitalia, scant pubic and axillary hair, absent uterus and fallopian tubes, and a rudimentary vagina. Menses does not occur because of the lack of cyclic progesterone and estrogen, and the lack of a functional uterus with endometrial lining. Patients show increased concentrations of testosterone, estrogen, and luteinizing hormone on laboratory evaluation. Diagnosis is made with karyotype analysis showing XY chromosomes in a patient with phenotypically female characteristics.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder with a wide range of presentations. Cutaneous manifestations include an erythematous rash over the malar cheeks that spares the nasolabial folds after sun exposure or discoid lesions with hyperpigmented edges and pink, atrophic centers. Painless oral ulcers and nonspecific hair loss may also occur. Fatigue, joint pain, and fever are also common presenting signs. Lupus nephritis is a common complication of SLE, particularly in younger women. Patients with lupus nephritis typically present with evidence of active SLE and may additionally display oliguria or anuria, signs and symptoms of hypertension (eg, headache, visual disturbance), uremia (eg, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, altered mental status), hyperkalemia (eg, peaked T waves on ECG), and hypervolemia with peripheral edema. Lupus nephritis involves glomerular deposition of antibodies, including IgG, IgM, and IgA, as well as activation of the classical complement pathway. Laboratory studies therefore generally show hypocomplementemia with decreased serum concentrations of early classical pathway components such as C1q, C2, C3, C4, and CH50, as well as increased creatinine. Kidney biopsy is useful for disease staging and may show a range of histologic patterns from mesangial glomerulonephritis to diffuse proliferative or membranous glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies therefore generally show hypocomplementemia with decreased serum concentrations of early classical pathway components such as C1q, C2, C3, C4, and CH50, as well as increased creatinine. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of exertional-induced wheezing, chest tightness, dyspnea, and tachypnea are suggestive of an asthma exacerbation. Asthma is characterized by the reversible obstruction to airflow caused by spasm of smooth muscle in the bronchi and small airways. It is often triggered by an allergen (eg, smoke, pollen), exercise, or temperature change. In the case of allergen-induced asthma, bronchoconstriction is triggered by IgE-mediated activation of mast cells, followed by degranulation and histamine release. Such mast cell activation is classified as a type | hypersensitivity reaction. These reactions are composed of two phases, the immediate and the late phase. In the immediate phase, preformed IgE on the surface of mast cells and basophils is crosslinked by an antigen leading to their degranulation and release of histamine, which results in vasodilation, vascular permeability, and bronchoconstriction among other effects. The late phase occurs hours after the initial insult and is mediated by the release of prostaglandins and leukotrienes synthesized by the mast cells. Treatment for asthma depends on the classification (intermittent, mild/moderate/severe persistent). In the case of exacerbations triggered by allergens, agents that act on mast - 4 r @ 3 5 SYA @ € > ©  g

Similarly, increased neutrophil-endothelial cell adhesion (

While it may trigger a concomitant asthma exacerbation, it is not the direct mechanism. Increased pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure (

Increased pulmonary vascular tone, chronic hypoxia, venous thromboembolic disease, and left-sided heart failure are many mechanisms that increase pulmonary vascular resistance. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This infant with a recent gastrointestinal illness has a presentation consistent with dehydration. Dehydration is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, based on the presenting signs and symptoms. Patients with mild dehydration will present with normal vital signs as well as normal mental status and urine output. Patients with moderate to severe dehydration may present with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, delayed capillary refill, lethargy, sunken fontanelles, and decreased urine output. Patients with moderate to severe dehydration should receive an initial bolus of 20 cc/kg of intravenous crystalloid (eg, normal saline, lactated ringers) for volume expansion. Patients with severe dehydration and hypovolemic shock can quickly decompensate and progress to cardiovascular collapse if not adequately resuscitated, and therefore, should be frequently re-evaluated with additional fluid boluses given if needed.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's prior illness and current presentation are highly concerning for congestive heart failure caused by mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease). Kawasaki disease is a multisystem vasculitis in children characterized by fever for at least 5 days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, a polymorphous rash, lymphadenopathy, erythema and edema of the hands and feet, and erythema affecting the mucous membranes with dry, cracked lips. To diagnose Kawasaki disease, fever for 5 days or more plus four of the remaining criteria are required. Laboratory studies may show thrombocytosis and increased ESR. Complications of Kawasaki disease include coronary artery aneurysms, and, if untreated, can lead to aneurysmal expansion, rupture, myocardial infarction, and/or congestive heart failure. Therefore, children suspected of having Kawasaki disease require immediate evaluation with ECG and echocardiography, treatment, and monitoring for progression or complications. Treatment of Kawasaki disease involves high-dose aspirin and intravenous immunoglobulin, and is the only widely accepted indication for aspirin use in febrile children due to the risk for Reye syndrome. Kawasaki disease is one of the most common pediatric vasculitides and a cause of pediatric heart disease. . 4 r @ 3 5 SYA @ € > ©  g

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Influenza-induced myositis is a common cause of viral induced myositis and triggered by influenza A or influenza B infection. Most patients report associated viral symptoms such as fever, anorexia, and arthralgias. Myositis may occur during active infection or after the infection, and symptoms include myalgias and tenderness. Additional symptoms range from mild weakness to quadriparesis, in addition to rhabdomyolysis. Laboratory analysis may show increased creatinine kinase activity, in addition to myoglobinuria. Testing for influenza virus is diagnostic for influenza-induced myositis in the setting of appropriate signs and symptoms plus additional supporting laboratory features.

Diagnosis is made with a combination of clinical findings and serologic testing, including antinuclear antibody, anti-Jo-1, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2 antibodies. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This pediatric patient with vulvar erythema and white vaginal discharge likely has vulvovaginitis. Candida albicans is a fungal pathogen that causes a variety of infections, including vulvovaginitis, urethritis, thrush, and sepsis. Patients with vulvovaginitis may present with an erythematous rash, vaginal itching, and thick, white discharge. Examination is characterized by thick, white, coarse discharge, and diagnosis is via pseudohyphae on microscopy. Common risk factors include diabetes mellitus and recent antibiotic or corticosteroid use. Treatment of superficial cutaneous candidiasis infection is with topical antifungal medications such as nystatin.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient with rhinorrhea, mild cough, low-grade fever, and bilateral cervical adenopathy has a presentation consistent with viral rhinosinusitis. Acute rhinosinusitis (ARS) is defined as symptomatic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal cavity lasting less than 4 weeks and can be classified as either viral or bacterial. Most cases of ARS are viral in cause, with rhinovirus, influenzavirus, and parainfluenza virus being the most implicated pathogens. Patients with viral rhinosinusitis may present with cough, nasal congestion, clear or purulent nasal discharge, and facial pain that is worse when leaning forward. In viral rhinosinusitis, fever, if present, typically resolves after 24 to 48 hours. Physical examination may show tenderness to percussion over the sinuses. Treatment of viral rhinosinusitis involves supportive care with over-the-counter analgesics, antipyretics, saline nasal spray, and oral or intranasal decongestants. Antibiotics are not indicated unless bacterial infection is suspected. . w e @ ° + say G € > o  ©

Bilateral cervical lymphadenitis often occurs secondary to viral upper respiratory infections, while unilateral cervical lymphadenitis is often bacterial in cause. This patient's lymph nodes are nontender.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Angelman syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the microdeletion of the maternally inherited chromosome region 15q11-13, which contains the gene for the ubiquitin pathway protein UBE3A. Angelman syndrome is characterized by abnormal development of particular areas of the brain (eg, hippocampus, cortex, cerebellum) in which the paternally inherited copy of UBE3A is inactivated through imprinting (an epigenetic process involving selective gene inactivation through DNA and histone methylation), thus creating a reliance on the maternally inherited copy for normal development. In contrast, microdeletion of paternally inherited UBESA leads to the different clinical presentation of Prader-Willi syndrome. Children with Angelman syndrome present with characteristic signs and symptoms, including severe developmental delay and cognitive disability, seizures, ataxia, speech delay, and microcephaly. Patients typically also display a happy, excitable demeanor, uncontrolled laughter, and repetitive hand flapping movements. Other findings may include characteristic facial features (eg, flat posterior aspect of the head, prominent mandible with widely spaced teeth and protruding tongue) strabismus, sleep disturbances, and a notable fascination with water. - 4 r @ 3 5 SYA @ € > ©  g

Chromosome 15 deletion, paternally inherited (
distractor_explanations.C: is implicated in Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with hyperphagia (and potential obesity), short stature, impaired cognition, motor delays, and hypogonadism. Mutation of MECP2 gene (
distractor_explanations.D: , on the X chromosome, results in Rett syndrome, which presents in females with microcephaly, cognitive and language impairment, loss of motor skills, seizures, repetitive hand wringing movements, and scoliosis. Patients may display autism spectrum disorder-like features with lack of social interest and eye contact. Trisomy 15 (
distractor_explanations.E: is a rare cause of Angelman syndrome in the setting of uniparental disomy, in which paternal nondisjunction of chromosome 15 occurs, followed by maternal loss of 15q11-13. However, microdeletion of 15q11-13 without uniparental disomy is more common. Complete trisomy 15 is typically lethal in utero. Trisomy 21 (
distractor_explanations.F: is the cause of Down syndrome, which presents with characteristic physical features including broad, flat, facial features with prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. Patients with Down syndrome also present with cognitive impairment, cardiac abnormalities (eg, atrial septal defect), gastrointestinal abnormalities (eg, duodenal atresia, imperforate anus), ophthalmologic abnormalities (eg, refractive errors), and hearing loss.

reasonably well but often needs to be awakened to feed. Examination shows an umbilical hernia, mild jaundice, and cool extremities. Growth is appropriate
for age. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital hypothyroidism typically presents without symptoms due to placental crossing of maternal thyroid hormone. However, if hypothyroidism is left untreated, infants may develop lethargy, hypothermia, feeding problems, hoarse cry, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, hypotonia, umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice caused by impaired feeding and decreased bilirubin conjugation, and dry skin. Intellectual disability in childhood may develop. Diagnosis requires evaluation of thyroid function tests, which typically shows increased TSH and decreased thyroxine (T4) concentrations at birth. In patients with decreased thyroid hormone concentrations on serum testing, thyroid scans and thyroid-binding globulin concentrations help elucidate the cause of hypothyroidism (eg, distinguishing between thyroid dysgenesis and defective thyroid hormone synthesis). Management requires proactive newborn screening and levothyroxine therapy.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Salmonella enteritidis is a motile, gram-negative bacillus that is a major cause of diarrhea worldwide. In the United States, it is most associated with undercooked poultry, eggs, or meats, and in some cases has been associated with pets (eg, turtles, reptiles, chickens). The incubation period typically ranges from 8 to 72 hours and patients will subsequently develop diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Bloody stools are common in children and Salmonella gastroenteritis is usually self- limited, with fevers resolving within 3 days and diarrhea resolving in approximately 1 week. Supportive care, including oral rehydration, is the cornerstone of management and antibiotics are not generally recommended in immunocompetent individuals with mild to moderate infections. Stool studies may show gram- negative bacilli. $ w e @ ° + + G € > o  ©

29. A 2-day-old full-term newborn is brought to the physician because of bilateral eye discharge. He was delivered at home by his father and has not yet been
examined by a physician. He appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked swelling of the eyelids; there is profuse yellow
discharge from both eyes. The conjunctivae cannot be visualized because of the swelling. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the
most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gonococcal conjunctivitis is the result of direct inoculation of bacteria from the genital canal to the newborn's eyes during the process of delivery. Patients present with erythema, profuse purulent discharge, eyelid swelling, and lymphadenopathy. Gram stain of purulent discharge will show gram-negative diplococci. In the hospital setting, erythromycin eye drops are provided to newborns at the time of delivery to prevent gonococcal conjunctivitis. Newborns diagnosed with gonococcal conjunctivitis should be hospitalized, cultures should be obtained, and patients should be provided ceftriaxone. Patients may also be provided artificial tears until their condition improves.

30. A22-month-old boy has had fever, vomiting, and diarrhea for 3 days. His mother has been supplementing his usual diet with extra nondairy liquids during
this period. He has had 12 to 15 diarrheal stools each day. She says that it is difficult to distinguish stool from urine when she changes his diaper. His
temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 32/min. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na* 135 mEq/L
cl- 115 mEq/L
K* 4.8 mEq/L
HCO,- 10 mEq/L
Urine pH 5.0
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.28
Pco, 30 mm Hg
Po, 108 mm Hg
HCO, 10 mEq/L
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his acid-base disorder?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for his acid-base disorder?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's laboratory studies and arterial blood gas analysis show a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis with partial compensation. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis is identified by a pH less than 7.35 (acidemia), with decreased Pcoz and HCO; . The respiratory system compensates for the acidosis by increasing minute ventilation, which eliminates carbon dioxide, an acid. This results in decreased Pcog and increased pH back toward normal range. This patient's persistently decreased pH suggests that respiratory compensation is only partial. Metabolic acidosis describes a derangement involving excess acid and is subdivided into anion gap and non-anion gap categories. Anion gap [Na] - ([CI"] + [HCO37]) calculates unmeasured anions in serum, which are contributing to acidity, whereas non-anion gap acidosis generally results from excess supply of protons or chloride, retention of protons or chloride by the kidney, or failure to secrete bicarbonate buffers. Non- anion gap acidosis is often a hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, as seen in this patient. Causes of non-anion gap acidosis include infusions of normal saline, Addison disease, renal tubular acidosis, and gastrointestinal losses of bicarbonate (eg, diarrhea). In the case of diarrhea or gastrointestinal disturbance, such as in this patient, bicarbonate secreted in the small intestine is normally reclaimed in the large intestine in exchange for chloride ions. If the colon cannot reclaim bicarbonate, such as following colectomy or during diarrheal illness, the concentration of serum chloride will remain increased and serum bicarbonate decreased.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that plays an important role in the synthesis of several coagulation factors, including factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as proteins C and S. Primary sources of vitamin K include leafy green vegetables and endogenous production by intestinal bacterial flora. Vitamin K deficiency is common in newborns due to poor placental transfer of vitamin K, low concentrations of vitamin K in breast milk, as well as immature neonatal intestinal flora and poor absorption. Vitamin K deficiency presents with signs and symptoms of bleeding (also known as hemorrhagic disease of the newborn), which may include cutaneous bleeding (eg, bruising, petechiae, oozing from venipuncture sites), hematomas, epistaxis, or gastrointestinal, retroperitoneal, or intracranial hemorrhage. All newborns should be administered prophylaxis with intramuscular vitamin K. Newborns with evidence of bleeding should be treated with oral or intravenous replacement of vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP), although treatment should be tailored according to the type and severity of bleeding. FFP contains all coagulation factors, as well as fibrinogen and proteins C and S.

had only two wet diapers. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and weighed 3317 9 (7 lb 5 cz), He was exclusively
breast-fed during his first 3 weeks of life; for the past 2 weeks, his diet has consisted of a cow milk-based formula. He has been taking 4 to 5 oz per feeding
and, until yesterday, had minimal spitting up after each feeding. At his most recent examination 1 week ago, he weighed 4224 g (9 lb 5 02). Today, he
EEEEETEMoxamination shows no other abnormalities. After the examination, he is given a bottle of formula, drinks 4 oz, and vomits
a large amount. This patient most likely has an obstruction at which of the following locations?

question_stem: most likely has an obstruction at which of the following locations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pyloric stenosis is a disorder of the pyloric sphincter that occurs in young infants and can result in partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus and an inability to relax the pyloric sphincter. Infants classically present within the first 1 to 2 months of life with forceful nonbilious emesis. Physical examination is notable for a characteristic ovoid mass in the epigastric region. The recurrent emesis, if severe, may result in signs of volume depletion and malnutrition. Laboratory studies typically show a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis as a result of the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid and potassium ions. Additionally, the resultant volume depletion causes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in renal losses of potassium and protons. Confirmatory diagnosis is made by ultrasound imaging to evaluate the thickness and length of the pyloric muscle. Patients are treated with surgical pyloromyotomy to relieve the stenosis. . w e @ 6 + say G € > o  ©

distractor_explanations.A: is the location of obstruction in patients with duodenal atresia, which is caused by failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen. Duodenal atresia presents with vomiting and abdominal distension within the first few days after birth in complete atresia. Gastroesophageal junction (
distractor_explanations.B: is the location of obstruction in achalasia. Achalasia is an esophageal dysmotility disorder resulting from deficient peristalsis as a result of impaired neuromuscular transmission and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. It manifests as dysphagia, odynophagia, weight loss, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food. It is typically diagnosed between ages 25 and 65 years and is rare in children. Jejunum (
distractor_explanations.C: may undergo atresia in a fetus secondary to an ischemic event, which may have various causes, such as maternal cocaine use, malrotation with volvulus, or other idiopathic causes. Patients may present with vomiting and abdominal distension on the first day of life, similar to patients with duodenal atresia. Midesophagus (
distractor_explanations.D: is the location of obstruction in patients with a vascular ring. A vascular ring is a congenital malformation of the aortic arch and/or great vessels that encircles the trachea and midesophagus. In addition to dysphagia, vomiting, and feeding problems, patients may present with stridor and respiratory difficulties.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Erythema toxicum neonatorum is a common, benign skin eruption of newborns that typically begins in the days following delivery and lasts from hours to days. This condition is characterized by 1- to 2-mm pale to yellow papules or pustules with an erythematous base, typically found on the trunk. Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation. If performed, a bedside Wright stain of vesicular fluid would show numerous eosinophils. Reassurance that the rash will resolve in a few days following diagnosis should be provided to the newborn's parents. Erythema toxicum, in isolation, follows a benign and harmless course.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertension is an increasing finding among pediatric and adolescent patients as rates of obesity have risen. Childhood and adolescent hypertension is associated with both an increased risk for persistent hypertension during adulthood and an increased risk for adverse cardiovascular events in later life. In adolescent patients, hypertension is defined as a blood pressure greater than the 95th percentile. Accurate blood pressure measurement is essential for staging and aids in guiding treatment and blood pressure recheck intervals. Oscillometric devices are commonly used for hypertension screening and routine office measurements, but frequently overestimate both systolic and diastolic blood pressures. If initial measurement by an oscillometric device reading is high, repeat measurements by auscultation should be performed and averaged to determine the patient's stage of hypertension. Initial treatment of hypertension is with lifestyle modifications targeting modifiable risk factors, such as obesity.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient, with fever, petechiae, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory findings of pancytopenia, has a presentation concerning for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). ALL is a common pediatric malignancy of B- or T-lymphocytes that may present with malaise, fatigue, weight loss, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, with circulating leukemic blasts on peripheral blood smear. Diagnosis is confirmed with bone marrow biopsy showing >20% lymphoblasts. B-lymphocyte malignancies are more common than T-lymphocyte malignancies, and evaluation with flow cytometry is necessary to determine the specific type of malignant cell, followed by mutational analyses. Treatment typically entails chemotherapy and many patients with ALL will enter remission. Bone marrow transplant can be curative in many cases.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is common variable immunodeficiency (CVID). The exact cause and pathogenesis are unknown; however, the disease is characterized by combined T- and B-lymphocyte defects, dysfunction in B-lymphocyte differentiation, and a decrease in serum concentration of all immunoglobulins, as seen in this patient's laboratory studies. It commonly presents in the second to fourth decades of life with recurrent upper respiratory, pulmonary, and gastrointestinal infections. Patients may develop bronchiectasis as a result of recurrent airway infection and inflammation. CVID is also associated with persistent diarrhea as a result of chronic Giardia lamblia infection. Physical examination may show lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. The mainstays of treatment include intravenous immunoglobulin replacement therapy and antibiotics. CVID is strongly associated with lymphoma and autoimmune conditions.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pervasive developmental disorder, which has been reclassified as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), includes a group of neurodevelopmental/neurodivergent syndromes that are characterized by atypical forms of social communication and interaction. 43. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother 3 hours after she refused to get out of bed this morning. Over the past 4 days, she has had

fever, malaise, and severe pain in her elbows, wrists, and knees. The family recently lived in a refugee camp. She appears flushed and acutely ill. Her

pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/40 mm Hg. The knee and ankle joints are warm and swollen. A grade 4/6 holosystolic

murmur is heard at the apex and radiates to the left axilla. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is rheumatic fever, characterized by arthritis and a murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Rheumatic fever is a sequela of untreated Streptococcus (group A) infection, commonly pharyngitis, in which there is a type II hypersensitivity reaction to self-antigens having a similar structure to, and thus molecularly mimicking, streptococcal M protein. Diagnosis is made by the Jones criteria, which describe many of the core clinical features of rheumatic fever, including the major criteria of polyarthritis, carditis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, and Sydenham chorea, as well as minor criteria of fever, leukocytosis, arthralgia, and PR interval prolongation. Patients often have an increased antistreptolysin O titer. Complications of rheumatic fever include mitral valve inflammation leading to long-term sequelae of chronic mitral valve regurgitation, prolapse, or stenosis. Treatment of the initial streptococcal infection is effective for reducing the risk for developing rheumatic fever. Per American Heart Association guidelines, once rheumatic fever has developed, treatment includes salicylates and a prolonged course of monthly penicillin treatments to reduce the risk for recurrence and further valvular damage. w e @ ° + say ic € > o  g

Severe cases may be complicated by diffuse hemorrhagic disease and/or distributive shock. Lyme disease (

Later stages of Lyme disease can be characterized by carditis, atrioventricular heart block, facial nerve palsy (which may be bilateral), migratory arthralgias, and, if left untreated, encephalopathy and chronic arthritis. Malaria (

Plasmodium falciparum infection can be complicated by severe disease, including cerebral malaria and acute kidney injury. Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease) (

In children, the disease is characterized by fever for at least 5 days, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, a polymorphous rash, lymphadenopathy, erythema and edema of the hands and feet, and erythema affecting the mucous membranes with dry, cracked lips. Typhoid fever (
distractor_explanations.F: is caused by the gram-negative bacillus Salmonella typhi and typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and nonbloody diarrhea. Physical examination may show a characteristic rash of small red macules (called rose spots) that spreads from the trunk to the extremities.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pyloric stenosis is a disorder of the pyloric sphincter that occurs in young infants and can result in partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus and an inability to relax the pyloric sphincter. Infants classically present within the first 1 to 2 months of life with forceful, nonbilious emesis. Physical examination is notable for a characteristic ovoid mass in the epigastric region. The recurrent emesis, if severe, may result in signs of volume depletion and malnutrition. Laboratory studies typically show a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis caused by the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid and potassium ions. Additionally, the resultant volume depletion causes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in renal losses of potassium and protons. Confirmatory diagnosis is made with ultrasonography to evaluate the thickness and length of the pyloric muscle. Patients are treated with surgical pyloromyotomy to relieve the stenosis.
explanation.educational_objective: Pyloric stenosis presents at several weeks of life and is characterized by repeated nonbilious vomiting after feedings, leading to dehydration and a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease from the spirochete Treponema pallidum that can present in multiple stages. Primarily syphilis presents with a painless chancre (ulcer) of the genitalia. There are typically no systemic signs or symptoms of syphilis infection at this stage. Rapid plasma reagin can be falsely negative in the primary stage of syphilis. Dark-field microscopy of fluid from the chancre is the most sensitive test for diagnosis of primary syphilis. The treatment for primary syphilis is a single benzathine Penicillin G intramuscular injection. Testing and treatment for additional sexually transmitted infections is appropriate, as they often coinfect patients.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The first approach in assessing incidentally found proteinuria in a healthy asymptomatic child is to repeat the urinalysis. The most common cause of proteinuria in asymptomatic children is transient proteinuria secondary to other causes such as fever, stress, exercise, and dehydration. In addition, proteinuria can be orthostatic or postural, with increased protein in a standing or upright position that normalizes when a patient is supine or recumbent. Orthostatic proteinuria is common in adolescent males. A repeat urinalysis on awakening would likely show a normal urinalysis, and a urinalysis at bedtime would show proteinuria. In a patient with persistent proteinuria, further workup should be done to evaluate kidney disease.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Developmental dysplasia of the hip occurs as the result of an abnormal or poorly developed acetabulum in infants. Risk factors include female sex, breech position during delivery, and family history of the condition. In infants, there may be an associated limb-length discrepancy and inability to abduct the limb. In infants, the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers may be used to test for hip instability and help diagnose developmental dysplasia of the hip. Additional testing including ultrasonography may be useful to diagnose infants younger than age 4 months. If left untreated, developmental dysplasia of the hip may result in functional disability, pain, and early osteoarthritis. The most common treatment for infants with this condition is an abduction splint, most commonly the Pavlik harness.
explanation.educational_objective: Developmental dysplasia occurs as the result of abnormal acetabular development, which leads to femoral instability. Patients may present with limb-length discrepancy and decreased abduction. Diagnosis can be made with the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers, as well as ultrasonography. Patients with developmental dysplasia of the hip benefit from an abduction splint to prevent long-term complications, including functional disability. w e 7 ° : — 6 € > o  4B

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: For this healthy, adolescent female patient, preventive measures will primarily address her sexual health. The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening all sexually active women under age 25 years for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. C. trachomatis is a common sexually transmitted infection that can cause various infections, including cervicitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, epididymitis, and urethritis. However, in many cases it is asymptomatic, and thus, screening asymptomatic patients is important for finding and treating active infections before long-term sequelae develop. C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae commonly coinfect the same patient.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The clinician should offer testing for sexually transmitted diseases, or sexually transmitted infections (STIs), at this time. STIs including chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis, are a major public health concern as they are often asymptomatic and can cause significant complications if left untreated. Adolescents are an at-risk demographic, especially as stigma regarding sexual activity and concerns about confidentiality may make individuals uncomfortable in disclosing any exposures or concerns regarding STIs. Urinary symptoms are a common presenting complaint for sexually active patients, and urinary tract infections (UTIs) often occur concurrently with STIs. Patients presenting with clinical findings of infection, such as dysuria and pyuria in this case, should be evaluated for both urinary tract infections and sexually transmitted infections, and appropriate treatment based on the results should be prescribed.

50. A6-month-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. He is exclusively fed cow milk-based formula. His mother reports that he takes his

bottle vigorously, but he frequently spits up after eating. He has not had diarrhea or fever. Development is appropriate for age. He has dropped from the 50th

percentile to the 35th percentile for weight since his last visit 2 months ago. Length and head circumference remain at the 50th percentile. Examination

shows decreased subcutaneous fat. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gastroesophageal reflux disease is extremely common in infants. This is the result of diminished closing pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter, permitting acidic contents of the stomach to reflux into the esophagus. Reflux events may occur up to 30 times per day. Some of these episodes result in contents entering the oral cavity and decrease through the first year of life. Infants who demonstrate good weight gain, are feeding well, and are not irritable, are managed conservatively. Modifications that may improve symptoms include having infants avoid secondhand smoke exposure, smaller and more frequent meals, and keeping infants upright after feeding when possible. Infants who experience reflux and poor weight gain should undergo further evaluation for calorie count, ultrasonography to rule out pyloric stenosis, and have their diets adjusted to thickened feeds or breast milk. In patients with refractory cases, a trial of proton pump inhibitors may be warranted.
explanation.educational_objective: Gastroesophageal reflux disease is extremely common in healthy infants because of diminished closing pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter. Infants who demonstrate good weight gain, are feeding well, and not irritable, are managed conservatively with lifestyle interventions. Infants experiencing weight loss should undergo nutritional workup, may undergo ultrasound testing, and start a trial of proton pump inhibitors to prevent worsening. Formula-fed children may require thickened feeds or transition to breast milk for improvement of their condition. 4 e @ ° . — @ € > o  Bg
